A1.T1.caption: Table 1. General Terminology
A1.T1.table:
Term Meaning
FL Federated Learning.
GD Gradient Descent.
DCGD Distributed Compressed Gradient Descent.
TEE Trusted Execution Environments.
DP Differential Privacy.
MPC The term is overloaded. In the context of Federated Learning literature typically means Multi-Party Computation.
HE Homomorphic Encryption.
IoT The collective network of connected devices.
references: Our work is multidiscipline. To make our paper more readable for researchers with different backgrounds, we have constructed this Glossary.

In the Ring of polynomials Kâ€‹[X]ğ¾delimited-[]ğ‘‹K[X] there is no division in general similar to Algebra Nğ‘N. However, itâ€™s possible to perform division with residual. A1.T4.caption: Table 4. Cryptography Terminology
A1.T4.table:
Term Meaning
FHE Fully Homomorphic Encryption.
SWHE Somewhat Homomorphic Encryption.
LFHE Leveled Fully Homomorphic Encryption.
CKKS Cheon-Kim-Kim-Song Homomorphic Encryption schema, which is formally only SWHE.
AES Advanced Encryption Standard.
sk Secret Key.
pk Public Key.
Symmetric Encryption Encryption schema in which secret and public key is the same.
PRP Pseudo Random Permutation.
PRF Pseudo Random Function.
MAC Message Authentication Code.
CRC Cyclic Redundancy Check.
CPA Chosen plaintext attack.
CCA Chosen ciphertext attack.
CTR Counter Mode Randomized.
CBC Cipher Block Chaining.
EAX Encrypt then Authenticate then Translate Mode.
LWE The Learning With Errors search problem to find a solution to a noisy system of linear equations in a finite field.
RLWE The Ring Learning With Errors search problem. Find a solution to a noisy system of the linear equation when an underlying algebra is a polynomial over a ring.
Integer Lattice It is a set of points which correspond to all possible linear combinations with integer coefficients of the nğ‘›n vectors biâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘b_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, i.e. it the set {x:x=âˆ‘i=1nÎ±iâ€‹bi,Î±iâˆˆâ„¤}conditional-setğ‘¥formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–â„¤\{x:x=\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\alpha}_{i}b_{i},{\alpha}_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}\}.
references: In this type, all the nodes are connected to a central master device with individual links. In the case of using DCGD/PermK, the master in this topology only plays the role of communication hub. Interestingly, while obtaining parts of the gradients from clients, computation is unnecessary, and synchronization is far more relaxed, as we have observed in AppendixÂ H.2. While using DCGD/PermK, the server can potentially utilize communication links with Full Duplex mode. Examples of Full Duplex communication buses include PCI-Express, InfiniBand777https://network.nvidia.com/pdf/whitepapers/HPC_Clustering_130.pdf, and some forms of Ethernet (see (Spurgeon, 2000) Table 4.1 in Chapter 4). In our setting, we consider the situation when clients are connected to the Internet, and as it has been described in AppendixÂ H.2, PCI-Express is not a bottleneck. However, in data centers, PCI-Express can also represent a bottleneck (Li etÂ al., 2019). With DCGD/PermK, during some period, a single link can be used simultaneously to obtain information from clients and deliver information to the clients. This is not the case for DCGD/RandK or GD because they require explicit synchronization. But it is the case for DCGD/PermK. This doubles the maximum bandwidth during master client communication and decreases latency by factor two.

FP Float point format.
Â Â Â Â  FP16, FP32, FP64 Float point format with a specified number of bits per single scalar.
CUDA Compute Unified Device Architecture.
CPU Central Processing Unit.
AVX Advanced Vector Extensions.
NIC Network Interface Controller.

1. GD [FP16|FP32|FP64] AlgorithmÂ 1, Baseline ( B), ğ’iâ€‹(x)=defxsuperscriptdefsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¥\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x.

Gradient Descend. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. Master obtains gradients from the clients and averages them. The master broadcasts the result directly to all clients. The specified Floating-Point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables in all clients and during aggregation in the master.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) Itâ€™s completely insecure (see AppendixÂ E.1). (2) Volume information from clients to master is ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘‘ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(dn) bytes per round. (3) Broadcasted information from master to clients is ğ’ªâ€‹(d)ğ’ªğ‘‘\mathcal{O}(d) bytes per round. For details on why information about âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x;Di)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ·ğ‘–\nabla f_{i}(x;D_{i}) can potentially reveal information about dataset Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} see discussion in ApeendixÂ E.1.
2. GD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/AES-128 AlgorithmÂ 1, Naive usage of AES ( A), ğ’iâ€‹(x)=defxsuperscriptdefsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¥\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x.

Gradient Descend with symmetric AES encryption which uses a key size of 128128128 bits (161616 bytes). In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. Then clients encrypt computed âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\nabla f_{i}(x) in parallel. After that Master collects the encoded gradients as a communication hub. Unfortunately master can not perform any algebraic operations, because âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\nabla f_{i}(x)are encrypted, and the master needs to broadcast all directions to the clients. The specified Floating-Point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables in all clients and during aggregation in the master. During using AES/EAX there exists a fixed negligible overhead from using EAX Mode Operation Mode of 323232 bytes in each client to master communication information transfer. Specifically, this Mode Operation includes the following overheads: Nonce - a random 161616-byte value, and the Tag - 161616-byte message authentication code.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) Master cannot average obtained encrypted clientsâ€™ local gradient. (2) Volume information from clients to master is ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹n+32â€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘‘ğ‘›32ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(dn+32n) bytes per round. (3) Broadcasted information from master to clients is ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹n+32â€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘‘ğ‘›32ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(dn+32n) bytes per round. For details about AES see ApeendixÂ F.
3. DCGD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/AES-128/RandK AlgorithmÂ 1, Naive usage of AES ( A), ğ’iâ€‹(x)=defdkâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆSxiâ‹…ei,Sâˆ¼u.a.r{s:sâˆˆ2[d],|s|=k}formulae-sequencesuperscriptdefsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–ğ‘†â‹…subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘’ğ‘–subscriptsimilar-toformulae-sequenceğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘†conditional-setğ‘ formulae-sequenceğ‘ superscript2delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘˜\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\frac{d}{k}\sum_{i\in S}x_{i}\cdot e_{i},S\sim_{u.a.r}\{s:s\in 2^{[d]},|s|=k\}.

Distributed Compressed Gradient Descend with symmetric AES encryption which uses a key size of 128128128 bits (161616 bytes), and with using RandK sparsifier. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. After this clients compress them by selecting kğ‘˜k components from dğ‘‘d u.a.r. Then clients use a sparse bitwise representation of the sparsified gradient and encode non-zero values with AES/EAX mode of operation. Then clients encrypt computed ğ’â€‹(âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x))ğ’âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\mathcal{C}(\nabla f_{i}(x)) in parallel. After that Master collects the encoded gradients as a communication hub. Unfortunately master can not perform any algebraic operations, because âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\nabla f_{i}(x)are encrypted, and the master needs to broadcast all directions to the clients. The specified Floating-Point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables in all clients and during aggregation in the master. During using AES/EAX there exists a fixed negligible overhead from using EAX Mode Operation Mode of 323232 bytes in each client to master communication information transfer. Specifically, this Mode Operation includes the following overheads: Nonce - a random 161616-byte value, and the Tag - 161616-byte message authentication code. The implementation of RandK sparsifier in the case of using a pseudo-random generator can be implemented in a way that no indices should be transferred during training because they can be reconstituted.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) Master cannot average obtained encrypted and compressed clientsâ€™ local gradient. (2) Volume information from clients to master is ğ’ªâ€‹(kâ€‹n+32â€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘˜ğ‘›32ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(kn+32n) bytes per round. (3) Broadcasted information from master to clients is ğ’ªâ€‹(kâ€‹n+32â€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘˜ğ‘›32ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(kn+32n) bytes per round. (4) Fundamentally there is some redundancy induced by the inability to perform aggregation in the master.
4. GD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/CKKS AlgorithmÂ 1, Baseline ( B), ğ’iâ€‹(x)=defxsuperscriptdefsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘¥\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x. Extra encryption is carried via employing CKKS.

In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. After this each client using the public key in CKKS schema performs encryption of gradient vectors. Master obtains the encoded gradients from the clients. Then master using a public key performs aggregation and relinearization to reduce the size of a ciphertext after arithmetic operations. After this master broadcast aggregated gradient estimator. Clients using private (secret) keys perform for decryption of the encrypted direction from the master and then make a step.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) CKKS encryption considerably increases ciphertext space. The volume of information from clients to master ğ’ªâ€‹(Câ‹…dâ€‹n)ğ’ªâ‹…ğ¶ğ‘‘ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(C\cdot dn) bytes, where Cğ¶C is a constant which depends on dğ‘‘d, security level, degree of the used polynomial, and cardinality of space â„¤qsubscriptâ„¤ğ‘\mathbb{Z}_{q} to represent integer coefficient of two transferred polynomials after encoding. (2) Size of public and private key to guarantee AES-128 for CKKS is approximately 420â€‰000420000420\,000 bytes, while for AES-128 the key size is 161616 bytes. In some tasks this key size is negligible, in some tasks, it is not. For details see AppendixÂ G. (3) CKKS does not operate on the level of bits only and can operate only with fp64 float point format in TenSeal implementation. Therefore there is no possibility of using less precision in combination with CKKS. For details about CKKS see AppendixÂ G.
5. DCGD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/RandK/CKKS AlgorithmÂ 1, Baseline ( B), ğ’iâ€‹(x)=defdkâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆSxiâ‹…ei,Sâˆ¼u.a.r{s:sâˆˆ2[d],|s|=k}formulae-sequencesuperscriptdefsubscriptğ’ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–ğ‘†â‹…subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘’ğ‘–subscriptsimilar-toformulae-sequenceğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘†conditional-setğ‘ formulae-sequenceğ‘ superscript2delimited-[]ğ‘‘ğ‘ ğ‘˜\mathcal{C}_{i}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}\frac{d}{k}\sum_{i\in S}x_{i}\cdot e_{i},S\sim_{u.a.r}\{s:s\in 2^{[d]},|s|=k\}. Extra encryption is carried via employing CKKS.

Distributed Compressed Gradient Descend with CKKS. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute the gradient for the function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} defined in Equation 2 in the current iterate. After this clients compress them by selecting kğ‘˜k components from dğ‘‘d u.a.r. After this each client using the public key in CKKS schema performs encryption of sparsified gradient vectors. Master obtains the encoded gradients from the clients. Then master using a public key performs aggregation and relinearization to reduce the size of a ciphertext after arithmetic operations. After this master broadcast aggregated gradient estimator. Clients using private (secret) keys perform for decryption of the encrypted direction from the master and then make a step.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) CKKS encryption considerably increases ciphertext space. The volume of information from clients to master ğ’ªâ€‹(Câ‹…dâ€‹n)ğ’ªâ‹…ğ¶ğ‘‘ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(C\cdot dn), where Cğ¶C is a big constant which depends on dğ‘‘d, security level, degree of the used polynomial, and cardinality of space â„¤qsubscriptâ„¤ğ‘\mathbb{Z}_{q} to represent integer coefficient of two transferred polynomials after encoding. For details see AppendixÂ G. (2) Size of public and private key to guarantee AES-128 for CKKS is approximately 420â€‰000420000420\,000 bytes, while for AES-128 the key size is 161616 bytes. In some tasks this key size is negligible, in some tasks, it is not. For details see AppendixÂ G. (3) CKKS does not operate on the level of bits only and can operate only with fp64 float point format in TenSeal implementation. Therefore there is no possibility of using less precision in combination with CKKS. (4) The CKKS does not support linear operations over sparse vectors from â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}. For HE schemas, encoding of any two vectors (e.g. sparse and dense) should be indistinguishable due to semantic security requirements. However, from a computational perspective, ignoring sparsity is sometimes highly impractical. This gap presents an open research question for HE.
6. DCGD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/PermK/AES AlgorithmÂ 3.

Distributed Compressed Gradient Descend with using PermK sparsifier. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute gradients in the current iterate. After this clients compress them by selecting kğ‘˜k components from dğ‘‘d jointly via using AlgorithmÂ 2. Then clients send a sparse bitwise representation of the sparsified gradient. Master collects the encoded gradients as a communication hub. The PermK compressor garantees that what is needed to perform at master is only concatenation. Therefore the algorithm can be implemented in practice in situations when the master can store, but cannot compute. The specified floating-point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables. The implementation of PermK in the case of using a pseudo-random generator can be implemented in a way, that no indices should be transferred during training because they can be reconstituted and negotiation between clients should be carried in runtime if clients have negotiated initial seed.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) There is 323232 byte overhead during message transfers compared to DCGD/RandK. (2) The current implementation works only in case dâ‰¥nğ‘‘ğ‘›d\geq n, when DCGD/RandK and GD/CKKS do not require this (3) Volume information from clients to master is ğ’ªâ€‹(d+32â€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘‘32ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(d+32n) bytes per round. (4) Broadcasted information from master to clients is ğ’ªâ€‹(d+32â€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘‘32ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(d+32n) bytes per round.
7. DCGD [FP16|FP32|FP64]/PermK AlgorithmÂ 3 in which Eâ€‹nâ€‹câ€‹râ€‹yâ€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹(x)=defxsuperscriptdefğ¸ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¥{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}Encrypt}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x, Dâ€‹eâ€‹câ€‹râ€‹yâ€‹pâ€‹tâ€‹(x)=defxsuperscriptdefğ·ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¥{\color[rgb]{0,0,1}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,1}Decrypt}(x)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def}}}{{=}}x.

Distributed Compressed Gradient Descend with using PermK sparsifier. In this algorithm, clients in a distributed way compute gradients in the current iterate. After this clients compress them by selecting kğ‘˜k components from dğ‘‘d jointly via using AlgorithmÂ 2. Then clients send a sparse bitwise representation of the sparsified gradient. Master collects the encoded gradients as a communication hub. The PermK compressor garantees that what is needed to perform at master is only concatenation. Therefore the algorithm can be implemented in practice in situations when the master can store, but cannot compute. The selected floating point format is used to represent both data and trainable variables. The implementation of PermK in case of using a pseudo-random generator can be implemented in a way, that no indices should be transferred during training because they can be reconstituted and negotiation between clients should be carried in runtime if clients have negotiated initial seed.

Quantitative and qualitative characteristics: (1) The current implementation works only in case dâ‰¥nğ‘‘ğ‘›d\geq n only, when DCGD/RandK and GD/CKKS does not require this. (2) This algorithm ignores privacy and security aspects. (3) Volume information from clients to master is ğ’ªâ€‹(d+32â€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘‘32ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(d+32n) bytes per round. (4) Broadcasted information from master to clients is ğ’ªâ€‹(d+32â€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘‘32ğ‘›\mathcal{O}(d+32n) bytes per round.
references: In our work, we made a comparison of several optimization algorithms with different compression and security methods. In TableÂ
below we summarize their qualitative and qualitative features.
